item.title: GG20 Proposal: Ma Earth Grants Round
item.dc:creator: metahands
item.description:
Name of Proposed Round

Ma Earth Grants Round

Funding for regenerative land projects.
@maearthmedia
maearth.eth

How many times has this round been run during a Gitcoin Grants round?

This is our first Ma Earth Grants Round. It‚Äôs an outgrowth of philanthropic grant-making by Biome Trust: https://biometrust.earth.

We have also been publishing an interview series featuring leading voices from the regenerative economy, and will use this audience to help get the word out: https://maearth.com

How big is your team that will run this round? Who is your team?

  • Matthew Monahan - Twitter / LinkedIn - completed the Grants Stack Round Manager training
  • Andre Bate - LinkedIn - experienced at running fellowship selection programmes
  • Catlin Powers - LinkedIn - solar energy entrepreneur and board trustee
  • Jan Hania - LinkedIn - MƒÅori conservation leader and foundation director

How does this round align with Gitcoin‚Äôs mission and essential intents?

The Ma Earth Grants Round is designed to support communities in funding and protecting their natural ecosystems and ecological commons.

By leveraging our existing relationship network of land projects, we can help bring values-aligned communities onchain and into the Gitcoin ecosystem for the first time.

As an established charitable foundation, we also have established networks with other funders and foundations. We aspire for our work to be a demonstration of the value of quadratic funding and Web3 tooling, and to help onboard other funders into future rounds across the Gitcoin ecosystem.

What do you anticipate the size of the matching pool will be?

Biome Trust is contributing US $100,000 to the matching pool for this round.

Funding address: 0xE9aaCeD9a50c79C10CdCBb943f0731d0e7AC6BBa

Who will be advisors for this round, if anyone?

The wider Biome Trust community will be involved in advising the round: https://biometrust.earth/about

Please describe the eligibility criteria you envision for this proposed round.

  • Place-based land projects, such as regenerative farms, eco villages, bioregional conservation, indigenous communities, and environmental education centers.

  • Ecologically regenerative activities, such as: tree planting, conservation easements, invasive species management, seed saving, wetland restoration, soil testing, biodiversity monitoring, renewable energy installations, and community gardens.

  • All rounds must comply with Gitcoin‚Äôs core rules, which include no fraudulent activity, quid pro quo, hate speech, or other activities out of alignment with Gitcoin‚Äôs essential intents.

How large is your community approximately?

We have active relationships with roughly 100 environmental nonprofits and land projects around the world. We are based in Aotearoa New Zealand and also have strong networks in the United States.

Our Ma Earth interview series audience is reaching thousands of people per month across social media channels.

We also have ten years of community networks and experience from our own regenerative land project, Mangaroa Farms (https://mangaroa.org).

What type of projects would you like to fund?

We are funding place-based, regenerative land projects that will help protect and restore ecosystems for the thriving of life on Earth.

We are choosing to focus this grants round on place-based projects, and not including intermediary environmental and advocacy groups at this time.

You can see the types of projects we‚Äôve supported in the past here: https://biometrust.earth/gifts

Approximately how many grantees do you believe will be eligible to apply to this round?

Since it‚Äôs our first round on the Gitcoin platform, we‚Äôre planning to keep the number of grantees tight, to approximately 10-20 projects, depending on the final applications we receive. We want to make sure we can deliver a high quality experience, especially since many of our grantees will be new to Web3 and crypto.

Impact Assessment: If and how do you intend to assess grantee impact over successive rounds? This could include, but is not limited to Hypercerts, GAP, Deresy, etc.

We are working to implement Hypercerts for scalable impact assessment, along with leading MRV (Measuring, Reporting, and Verification) providers to measure relevant ecological outomes (e.g. carbon, biodiversity, and water quality).

We will ask grantees to provide a summary of activities and impact, including when applying for subsequent rounds. We have a network of ecological advisors and experts to support us as needed in determining quality of outcomes.

Is there anything else that community members should consider when voting for which rounds to focus on in the upcoming GG20 grants round?

We are grateful to the Gitcoin community for continuing to provide tools and systems to support innovative funding models. We see this as a pillar of the future of philanthropic giving, and we are looking to use our rounds as a case study with other nonprofit foundations and donors. If successful, we also plan to commit more of our endowment to future grants rounds.

Part of our mission is also to support regenerative land projects getting onchain for the first time. We‚Äôve started creating a series of tutorials and help documentation to this aim. Work in progress.

We welcome any additional funds for the matching pool, as we believe in the importance of the work being done by grantees. That said, our primary motivation here is for the general visibility and support that would come from inclusion as a Gitcoin Community Round.

item.title: GG20 Proposal: Bountyverse Phase 1:Unearthing
item.dc:creator: Atlantian001
item.description:
1. Name of Proposed Round
Bountyverse Phase 1: Unearthing

2. How many times has this round been run during a Gitcoin Grants round?
This is our first time running a grants round. We have been grantees since GG14.

3. How big is your team that will run this round? Who is your team?
The team running this round will be

Reviewers:

  • Irthu
  • Nakul

Operations:

  • Madhav
  • Gopika

4. How does this round align with Gitcoin‚Äôs mission and essential intents?

Bountyverse is a comprehensive program, developed by Atlantis, This program merges the best aspects of hackathons, grants, and the focused direction of theme-driven innovations. Few months back we floated the idea with the community and received positive signal to further develop the program.

Our goal with Bountyverse is to assemble seasoned climate leaders (Bounty Masters) and scout for emerging climate talents (Bounty Hunters) and forge dynamic teams comprising of these changemakers. These teams then embark on a quest to conquer specific climate challenges (around resilience and regeneration) and eventually culminating in the creation of Climate Artifacts ‚Äì invaluable resources for climate resilience and accelerating the adoption of regenerative life support systems.

This year‚Äôs edition, Bountyverse 2024 will consist of 3 phases and span over 9 months. In this proposal we explain how we are using Gitcoin‚Äôs technologies for determining and allocating funds for the execution of Phase 1, titled ‚ÄúUnearthing‚Äù.

With Bountyverse we aim to addresses the crucial ‚Äúlast mile impact tracking‚Äù challenge in public goods funding, by developing a system that quantifies the impact of the funds allocated. Atlantis‚Äô suite of impact tools ensure complete transparency, offering all funders, including Gitcoin, end-to-end traceability regarding utilizing their funding to effect tangible change.

Bountyverse is designed for maximizing the impact of builders and is directly in alignment with Gitcoin‚Äôs mission of creating technologies to enable communities to build, fund and protect what matters.

Bountyverse is closely aligned with Gitcoin‚Äôs essential intents

Network Effects - Maximizing the network effects of our ecosystem to grow product adoption.

The aim of Bountyverse is to identify high quality founders who will in turn bring their established community members to the Gitcoin ecosystem. The eligibility criteria and fund allocation mechanism will drive grantees to onboard more community members hence maximizing the network effects of the Gitcoin ecosystem.

‚ÄúCommunity First - Cultivating a community that thrives on providing positive change and meaningful engagement‚Äù

Bountyverse brings new utilities to existing GTC holders and Passport holders as both these primitives are being integrated into Atlantis suite of Impact tools. We believe the program will bring more meaningful community engagement.

‚ÄúFinancial Longevity - Ensuring the economic health and vitality of Gitcoin‚Äù

Bountyverse will bring novel usecases to :

  • GTC (via Impact Bounty rewards),
  • Passport (used to protect bounties from sybil attack).
  • Increase the GMV of Allo protocol by using QF in multiple instances across Bountyverse ( in Phase 1 and in Phase 3)

5. What do you anticipate the size of the matching pool will be (either fundraised from partners, raised independently through your connections, or a combination of both)?

  • Total Target: $60K
  • Already Committed: $15K
  • Seeking matching amount from GG20 Pool: $25K
  • Team‚Äôs Remaining Target: $20K (from Bounty Sponsors + Existing Connection)

6.Please describe the eligibility criteria you envision for this proposed round.

  • Leadership Transparency: Eligible projects must have identified and doxxed leaders who are accountable and accessible. This transparency fosters trust and ensures project leaders are committed to their initiatives.
  • Proven Expertise: We seek founders with a solid track record in developing solutions that enhance climate resilience or have demonstrated capabilities in creating regenerative life support systems. This expertise is crucial for the success and impact of the funded projects.
  • Commitment to Community Engagement: Founders must commit to deploying at least 80% of the total funds received as bounties through the Citizen App. This approach ensures that the broader community is engaged and benefits from the project, fostering a collaborative ecosystem.
  • Transparency in Fund Utilization: Founders must be willing to share the outcomes and impacts of their fund deployment publicly. This transparency builds trust and provides valuable insights and lessons for the broader community.
  • Community and Project Maturity: Eligible projects should have been operational for at least three months, possess a healthy and engaging community, and have a verifiable online presence. This criterion ensures that funded projects have a solid foundation and are well-positioned to utilize the grant effectively.

7.How large is your community approximately?

  • Twitter: 4.3K
  • Beta Testers: 4.1K

8. What type of projects would you like to fund?

  • Climate Resilience Initiatives: We aim to fund projects that actively enhance the resilience of communities and ecosystems against the adverse impacts of climate change. This includes but is not limited to, initiatives focused on disaster preparedness, adaptive infrastructure, and sustainable resource management.
  • Regenerative Life Support Systems: Our funding priority includes projects dedicated to developing and implementing regenerative practices that restore, renew, and revitalize our planet‚Äôs ecosystems. Key areas of interest include wetland restoration, agroforestry, circular economy models, permaculture, and soft path energy & water systems.
  • Proven Impact and Artifact Creation capability: We are looking for projects with a track record of producing high-quality outputs, be they in the form of code, concepts, or content, that contribute significantly to their field. The ability to create tangible artifacts that demonstrate clear benefits and scalable impact is a critical factor in our funding decisions.
  • Community Engagement and Maturity: Eligible projects should have established a robust and active community presence. They must demonstrate a history of meaningful engagement, collaboration, and a commitment to collective action. We value projects supported by a dedicated following and show potential for broader community mobilization.
  • Beyond Decarbonization: While we acknowledge the importance of decarbonization efforts, our funding focuses on projects beyond carbon reduction. We seek to support initiatives that offer holistic and integrated solutions to environmental challenges, emphasizing restoration and regeneration over mere mitigation.

9. Approximately how many grantees do you believe will be eligible to apply to this round?

We are placing a strong emphasis on high quality founders leading established communities, hence we are enabling participation for a maximum of 20 projects.

It is imperative to note the second order effects these grantees will produce when they bring their community members to the Gitcoin ecosystem. Further, the eligibility criteria and the fund allocation mechanism of Bountyverse will ensure the infusion of a larger number of high quality members to the Gitcoin ecosystem.

10.Impact Assessment: If and how do you intend to assess grantee impact over successive rounds?

Atlantis has developed a suite of impact tools to capture, assess and measure end to end impact of projects within Bountyverse -

  • Impact Foundry : Grantees use this tool to deploy funds via impact bounties
  • Impact Miner : Grantees‚Äô communities use this product to take on impact bounties, capture data and get rewarded
  • GTC will be used as the token reward for Impact Bounties and will be integrated with Impact Foundry and Impact Miner.
  • Gitcoin passport will be integrated within the Impact Miner for sybil resistance and minimise double accounting of impact.

11.Is there anything else that community members should consider when voting for which rounds to focus on in the upcoming GG20 grants round?

This is our first application to run a grants round and we would love the opportunity to demonstrate the concept we have developed for last mile impact tracking which can be used to create high impact outputs and in the process produce high utility public goods artifacts.

Since Bountyverse is an annual event which spans 9 months, the program in its current format provides two unique opportunities every year to use Gitcoin‚Äôs technologies to build what matters. It also comes with promising potential to bring novel use cases to GTC, Passport and Allo especially in emerging markets and frontiers of web3 adoption.

12.Funding Address:

item.title: Defining Community at Gitcoin (Part 1) - Creating Shared Mental Models
item.dc:creator: CoachJonathan
item.description:
Introduction

Community has long been at the heart of Gitcoin‚Äôs operations and its success. That said, the term ‚Äúcommunity‚Äù is thrown around so often (especially in web3) that it has lost its meaning.

This post is meant to share some of the current thinking at the Ecosystem Collective as we strive to find better ways to engage Citizens in happenings at the DAO.

Before diving into the how, let‚Äôs take a step back and ensure we are operating from the same mental models of ‚Äúcommunity‚Äù so that Gitcoin‚Äôs strategies and tactics are a better match to who our community really is.

1. Community vs. Network

Though these words are used interchangeably, research shows that these different words have very different meanings:

Network: a web of interconnected personal relationships

  • relationships of trust are extendable, or as the saying goes: ‚Äòmy friend‚Äôs friend, is my friend‚Äô

Community: a group of individuals who share mutual concern for one another

Feature Network Community
Structure Loosely structured More tightly structured
Connections Weak ties, based on shared interests Strong ties, based on shared identity, purpose, or place
Purpose Primarily for sharing information or resources Primarily for belonging, support, and identity
Benefits Access to information, opportunities, and expertise Sense of belonging, support, and shared identity
Examples Professional network, online forum, social media group Religious congregation, neighborhood association, support group
Inclusivity Relatively open and easy to join May have membership requirements or qualifications

Most of Gitcoin‚Äôs ‚Äòcommunities‚Äô are actually networks.

Understanding this, we have two questions we can explore:

  1. How do we want to appropriately foster our networks (vs. our communities)?
  2. Where are actual communities present that Gitcoin might want to participate in or create from scratch?

These two questions help us explore: where and how do we want to focus our time and energy.

2. Community Engagement Methodology

We‚Äôre a fan of Orbit‚Äôs model to help us better contextualize the relationship between Gitcoin and individuals interacting with us (and with each other).

By modeling our community engagement strategy like this, we can communicate differently with individuals who are more/less engaged with Gitcoin while providing a clear path for individuals to deepen their relationship with us.

Each of Gitcoin‚Äôs sub-communities will have its own set of levels with defining characteristics.

3. Quality vs. Quantity

Generally we are finding a balance of optimizing our activities for two different results:

  • Deepening existing relationships
  • Inviting net new individuals into our ‚Äòorbit‚Äô

All with the goal of growing the ecosystem and creating an upward spiral of momentum and positive output.

Both of these elements will count toward a ‚Äúsuccessful‚Äù community engagement initiative. Whether one is more important than the other will come down to the individual goals of each sub-community, and will likely fluctuate over time depending on the results we are seeing (ex: if we are seeing tons of new individuals, but few individuals truly stepping up as community leaders, we will aim to start focusing on the latter).

4. Principles of Belonging

Charles Vogl‚Äôs book Art of Community outlines seven principles that can be implemented in a growing or emerging community. These principles will help us define and grow our communities.

Boundary: The line between members and outsiders

Initiation: The activities that mark a new member

Rituals: The things we do that have meaning

Temple: A place set aside to find our community

Stories: What we share that allows others and ourselves to know our values

Symbols: The things that represent ideas that are important to us

Inner Rings: A path to growth as we participate

These principles are intended to act as a guide vs. doctrine.

The post above was meant to highlight some of the thinking that is happening at the Ecosystem Collective wrt community engagement and with the goal of creating more opportunities for Citizens to get involved at Gitcoin.

Here are some promtps that we‚Äôd love to hear from you about:

  • Related to the above, what do you think is spot on? What have we missed?
  • What do you think are the most major Gitcoin networks/communities we should be focusing our attention on?
  • What has Gitcoin done well in the past? Where have we missed opportunities?
